title: The Devil with the Three Golden Hairs
author: Brothers Grimm

content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom far away, there lived a poor couple who had a little boy.
The child was born with a caul over his face, and it was said that whoever was born with such a sign would marry the king’s daughter when he turned fourteen.
The king, who was a proud and greedy man, heard of this prophecy and grew very angry.
He did not want his daughter to marry a poor boy, so he ordered his servants to take the child away and drown him in the river.
But the servants were kind-hearted and could not bring themselves to harm the innocent baby.
Instead, they placed him in a basket and set him adrift on the river, hoping someone would find him and raise him as their own.
The basket floated gently downstream until it was caught in the roots of a tree near a mill.
The miller and his wife, who had no children of their own, found the baby and took him in.
They loved him as their own son and named him Hans.
Years passed, and Hans grew into a strong and clever boy.
When he turned fourteen, the king happened to pass by the mill and saw him.
Recognizing the boy from the prophecy, the king’s heart filled with dread.
He called Hans to him and said, “Listen, boy. I have a task for you.
Take this letter to the queen. It is very important.”  Hans, who was honest and brave, agreed at once.
He set off on his journey, not knowing that the letter contained orders for the queen to have him killed as soon as he arrived.
Along the way, Hans grew tired and stopped to rest in a dark forest.
As he slept, a band of robbers crept up and stole his belongings—including the letter.
But one of the robbers, who had a kind heart, read the letter and was horrified by its contents.
He quickly wrote a new letter, saying that the queen should marry Hans to the princess at once, and placed it in Hans’s pocket.
When Hans arrived at the palace, the queen read the letter and was overjoyed.
She prepared a grand wedding feast, and Hans married the princess that very day.
The king, when he returned, was furious, but he could not undo what had been done.
Instead, he decided to send Hans on another impossible task, hoping he would never return.
“Go to the Devil’s Mountain,” the king said, “and bring me three golden hairs from the head of the Devil himself.
If you fail, you will never see the princess again.”  Hans, though frightened, agreed to the task.
He set off on his journey, determined to succeed.
Along the way, he met an old woman who asked where he was going.
When Hans told her, she warned him, “The Devil is a terrible creature, and his grandmother is even worse.
But if you are clever, you may yet survive.”  Hans thanked her and continued on his way.
When he reached the Devil’s Mountain, he found the Devil’s grandmother sitting outside a dark cave.
She was an old, wrinkled woman with sharp eyes, but she took pity on Hans when she heard his story.
“Very well,” she said. “I will help you, but you must be very careful.
My grandson, the Devil, is sleeping now, and if you wake him, he will tear you to pieces.
Hide under his bed and wait until he falls asleep again.
Then, pluck one golden hair at a time and ask him your questions.”  Hans did as she said.
He crept under the Devil’s bed and waited.
When the Devil returned, he was in a foul mood and grumbled, “I smell the blood of a human!” But his grandmother calmed him, saying it was just the wind.
The Devil lay down and soon fell into a deep sleep.
Hans plucked the first golden hair and asked, “Why does the fountain in the village no longer give wine?”  The Devil, half-asleep, muttered, “Ah, beneath the fountain lies a toad.

Kill it, and the wine will flow again.”  Hans plucked the second golden hair and asked, “Why does the tree in the forest no longer bear golden apples?”  The Devil groaned, “Beneath the roots lies a mouse.

Kill it, and the tree will bear golden apples once more.”  Hans plucked the third golden hair and asked, “Why does the ferryman on the river never rest?”  The Devil growled, “He must hand his oar to the next person who asks to be ferried across.
Then he will be free.”  With the three golden hairs in hand, Hans thanked the Devil’s grandmother and hurried back to the king.
Along the way, he helped the villagers by killing the toad and the mouse, and he told the ferryman how to free himself.
When he returned to the palace, the king was astonished to see him alive.
Hans handed over the three golden hairs, and the king, though disappointed, had no choice but to accept them.
But Hans was not done yet. He told the king about the ferryman and how he could be freed.
The greedy king, thinking he could use the ferryman’s endless labor to his advantage, rushed to the river and demanded to be ferried across.
The ferryman, remembering Hans’s words, handed the oar to the king and said, “Now you must take my place.”  And so, the king was trapped as the ferryman, doomed to row back and forth forever.
Hans and the princess lived happily ever after, ruling the kingdom with kindness and wisdom.
